author: news.com.au
title: MLB playoffs Blue Jays score Jose Bautista home run bat flip Texas Rangers Rougned Odor Russell Martin Shin-soo Choo
text:
Video Image Jose Bautista homer seal Blue Jays win 0:42 MLB: The Blue Jays qualify for their first ever American League Championship Series in over two decades after a Jose Bautista home run sees Toronto take the lead in an insane 7th inning
October 15th 2015 6 days ago /video/video.news.com.au/News/ Jose Bautista flips his bat as the game-winning homer soars into the crowd.
AP JOSE Bautista smashed a three-run homer in the seventh inning to power Toronto over the Texas Rangers 6-3 and advance the Blue Jays in the Major-league Baseball playoffs.
But that isn’t half of the story.
Toronto eliminated the Rangers 3-2 in the divisional series and reached the best-of-seven American League championship series for the first time since 1993.
“Unbelievable feeling. Unbelievable energy from the fans,” said Blue Jays catcher Russell Martin, a Canadian.
“This is awesome. Words can’t describe the feelings inside me.”
The Blue Jays — whose squad includes Aussie relief pitcher Liam Hendriks — will meet Kansas City in the championship series after the Royals secured a 3-2 series win over Houston.
Jose Bautista proved the difference for the Blue Jays. Source: Reuters
Trailing 3-2 on Thursday, the Blue Jays drew level when Josh Donaldson grounded into a bases loaded fielder’s choice.
That set the stage for 34-year-old Dominican outfielder Bautista’s decisive blast.
“For intensity and emotion, it was the most emotionally charged game I have ever played,” Bautista said.
“There was so much stuff going on. It was just the whole game, a do or die game. It was just the moment. I felt it. I did it. I’m just glad I was able to hit the heck out of the ball.”
Rangers leadoff batter Delino DeShields opened with a double, took third base on a Shin-Soo Choo’s ground out and scored when Prince Fielder grounded into a fielder’s choice.
Choo then smashed his second career playoff homer in the third inning to put the Rangers ahead 2-0.
Star Texas second baseman Rougned Odor can believe his team blew a late lead. Source: AFP
But the Blue Jays answered when Ben Revere scored from second on a Bautista double in the third inning and Edwin Encarnacion blasted a solo homer to level up in the sixth.
In the seventh, Texas second baseman Rougned Odor singled, advanced to third on two ground outs and scored on one of the most bizarre plays of this or any season.
Toronto catcher Martin was throwing the ball back to pitcher Aaron Sanchez when it struck Choo’s bat as he stood in the batter’s box. The ball dribbled onto the field and Odor, realising the ball was in play, raced home as the stunned Toronto fielders and fans looked on, umpires ruling he has scored the go-ahead run for the Rangers.
As supporters tossed bottles onto the field, the Blue Jays protested the call and the game but the decision stood, television replays showing the routine toss back to the mound deflected off Choo’s bat, an error on Martin.
“I just caught the ball and threw it back very casually,” Martin said.
“It hit his bat and they scored. I don’t know the rule. I had never had that happen before.
Unbelievable 7th inning in MLB play-off series 1:47 MLB: In one of the craziest innings in MLB play-off history a lengthy review decision hands Texas a controversial lead at the top of the 7th inning, only to see the Toronto Blue Jays hit back thanks to several unforced errors from Rangers fielders
October 15th 2015 6 days ago /video/video.news.com.au/News/ “You can either feel sorry for yourself or try and do something about it. We did something about it, capitalised on a couple mistakes and that’s what won us the game.”
Texas brought the tying run to the plate in the eighth but Toronto relief pitcher Roberto Osuna struck out Josh Hamilton and Elvis Andrus to end the inning. He also struck out pinch hitters Mike Napoli and Will Venable in the ninth for the final two outs of the game.
 Video: Bat flip caps off wild Blue Jays win
